perturbation.original_text: 3.3.1  For each month during the Term, the Company will pay CNET a                  minimum of [XXXX] in cash, plus [XXX] of CNET Sales. Payments                  under this paragraph will be based on the reports prepared by                  the Company under Section 3.2 (although CNET may challenge such                  reports as contemplated by Section 9.5) and will be due within                  30 days after the end of each month of the Term.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3.1  For each month during the Term, the Company will pay CNET a                  minimum of [XXXX] in cash, plus [XXX] of CNET Sales. Payments                  under this paragraph will be based on the reports prepared by                  the Company under Section 3.2 (although CNET may challenge such                  reports as contemplated by Section 9.5) and will be due within                  45 days after the end of each month of the Term.
perturbation.explanation: This introduces an inconsistency by changing the payment deadline from 30 days to 45 days. This conflicts with the original 30-day payment term, creating ambiguity and potential disputes over when payments are actually due.

perturbation.original_text: 3.3.2  Payments under this Section 3.3 will be made by wire transfer                  of immediately available funds and are nonrefundable once paid.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3.2  Payments under this Section 3.3 will be made by wire transfer                  or check, at the Company's discretion, and are nonrefundable except in cases of gross negligence or willful misconduct on CNET's part, as determined by a third-party audit.
perturbation.explanation: This introduces an inconsistency by allowing payment by check in addition to wire transfer, giving the Company more flexibility. It also contradicts the 'nonrefundable' clause by adding exceptions for CNET's gross negligence or willful misconduct. The terms of refund become uncertain.

perturbation.original_text:
4.   Term and Termination. The term of this Agreement (the "Term") will begin on      February 1, 1998 and end on the first anniversary of the date of this      Agreement; provided that (a) either party may terminate this Agreement,      effective at any time after the first three

       months of the Term, by giving 30 days' written notice of termination to the      other party, and (b) either party may terminate this Agreement at any time      by giving written notice of termination to the other party, if the other      party commits a material breach of its obligations hereunder that is not      cured within 30 days after notice thereof from the non-breaching party. If      this Agreement is terminated during any of the three month periods      referenced in Section 2.3.2, then the required number of Retail Impressions      applicable thereunder to such three month period will be pro rated      accordingly.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.   Term and Termination. The term of this Agreement (the "Term") will begin on      February 1, 1998 and end on the first anniversary of the date of this      Agreement; provided that (a) either party may terminate this Agreement,      effective at any time after the first three

       months of the Term, by giving 30 days' written notice of termination to the      other party, and (b) either party may terminate this Agreement at any time      by giving written notice of termination to the other party, if the other      party commits a material breach of its obligations hereunder that is not      cured within 60 days after notice thereof from the non-breaching party. If      this Agreement is terminated during any of the three month periods      referenced in Section 2.3.2, then the required number of Retail Impressions      applicable thereunder to such three month period will be pro rated      accordingly.
perturbation.explanation: This changes the cure period for a material breach from 30 days to 60 days. This creates a conflict, as one clause allows termination if a breach isn't cured in 30 days, while another requires a 60-day period, causing confusion over the actual timeframe for resolving breaches before termination.
